Mal Maiden: Murray Review hits and misses The Turnbull government has accepted most of the financial recommendations in the Murray Review, but not all, as Mal Maiden explains.
PT2M15S 620 349 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Complex financial instruments explained with barely decipherable language and flogged to mum and dad investors by big banks and other groups could be banned from sale by the corporate regulator under new powers being considered by the federal government.
The Turnbull government has agreed with a key recommendation from the financial system inquiry that would over time increase the powers of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.
It will help stop a race to the bottom.
Professor Kevin Davis Professor Kevin Davis, who sat on the FSI panel led by David Murray, said the government's acceptance of the recommendation would help to stop a "race to the bottom".
Kevin Davis wanted an ASIC oversight committee Photo: Michel O'Sullivan
 "There were enough instances of detriment to consumers – financial product consumers and investors – because of product failures. Part of the problem that arises, is that while you hope that reputable firms won't put out products that are not well designed for consumers there are always going to be some who will try and exploit financial consumers.
Advertisement "It will help stop a race to the bottom because one of the things we saw in the global financial crisis is when you've got entities putting out products that under-compete or under-cut other reputable firms there is often a tendency to follow suit to try and protect market share and margin."
The government plans to run an industry consultation program in the lead-up to giving ASIC the new power to ban dodgy or highly unsuitable products.
"We will consult with stakeholders on the development of a new ASIC product intervention power that could be used to modify products, or if necessary, remove harmful products from the marketplace," the official government response to the FSI said.
ASIC, which will on Wednesday give a formal response to the government's reply to the FSI when it fronts Senate Estimates, is understood to be very pleased with the expansion of its powers.
The Turnbull government has also backed a proposal to make issuers and distributors of financial products accountable for their offerings.
The consultation period on ASIC's product stopping powers will begin in mid-2016.
By the end of 2016, the government plans to consult on strengthening ASIC's enforcement tools in regards to financial services and credit licensing. The government will also consult on beefing up the civil penalty regime in Australia and to develop legislation to give ASIC the power to ban individuals from managing financial firms.
Professor Davis said he was disappointed the government did not agree to adopt the FSI recommendation to bring in a oversight committee for ASIC, saying the plan to expand the remit of the Financial Sector Advisory Committee to perform the same task was "problematic" because the FSAC was stacked with banking chief executives.
The Consumer Action Law Centre welcomed the government's decision to increase the powers of ASIC.
"A product intervention power will enable ASIC to amend or ban harmful financial products where there is risk of significant consumer detriment. When enacted, ASIC will be able to respond quickly when consumers are at risk, and intervene before harm has occurred," says Consumer Action chief executive Gerard Brody.
Professor Davis said it was important the government did not stifle innovation – a view shared by the Australian Bankers' Association.
ABA chief executive Steven Münchenberg said the banking lobby looked forward to working with the government and other stakeholders on the detail of reforms aimed at encouraging innovation in financial services and maintaining consumer protections.
"Financial services regulation must strike the right balance in protecting consumers and not stifling innovation and competition in financial products or creating inappropriate regulatory risks across the industry," he said.
